docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago I witnessed what seemed to be a medical miracle in a village deep in Bolivia: a nearly lifeless child dehydrated by severe diarrhea was given sips of a sugar and salt solution and recovered in a couple of hours. Curious about this simple yet lifesaving mixture called oral rehydration solution, I learned that United States-funded scientists had discovered it in 1968 in then-East Pakistan as a simple, cheap alternative to intravenous treatment. Defying all expectations, the researchers learned that at the right proportions, oral rehydration could resurrect even severely dehydrated adults suffering from cholera.

headline.main: A Sugar and Salt Solution for Haiti's Cholera Epidemic

docs.abstract: Guest blogger Josh Ruxin writes about how oral rehydration solution can save lives during Cholera outbreaks, like the one in Haiti.
docs.snippet: Guest blogger Josh Ruxin writes about how oral rehydration solution can save lives during Cholera outbreaks, like the one in Haiti.

docs.lead_paragraph: MADRID -- Twenty-one years ago, Antonio Meño Ortega, a keen mountaineer and law student in Madrid, entered into a coma after being accidentally deprived of oxygen while undergoing cosmetic surgery on his nose. Since then, his parents have fought a desperate, public legal battle to demonstrate that medical negligence led to their son's coma, in the process losing their fruit store, as well as their house, and still owing 400,000, now nearly $555,000, in legal costs.

headline.main: MADRID JOURNAL: From a Shelter, Parents Fight for a Comatose Son

docs.abstract: Madrid Journal; parents of Antonio Meno Ortega, who has been comatose for 21 years, are fighting desperate public legal battle that has cost them nearly everything to demonstrate that medical negligence led to their son's plight; family, which has camped outside the Justice Ministry for over 500 days, has finally won a review by the Supreme Court; photo (M)
